title-group.article-title: Experimental antibacterial and mineralizing calcium phosphate-based treatment for dentin surfaces

article-meta.aff: 1Guanghua School of Stomatology, Sun Yat-sen University, 56 Ling Yuan Xi Road, Guangzhou 510055, China
2Department of Biomaterials and Biomimetics, New York University College of Dentistry, New York, NY 10010, USA
3Guangdong Provincial Institute of Traditional Chinese Medicine, 60 Heng Fu Road, Guangzhou 510095, China
4Department of Basic Science and Craniofacial Biology, New York University College of Dentistry, New York, NY 10010, USA

author-notes.corresp: Junqi Ling, Guanghua School of Stomatology, Sun Yat-sen University, 56 Ling Yuan Xi Road, Guangzhou 510055, China. Email: Lingjq@mail.sysu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Objectives: This study aimed to determine the efficacy of experimental calcium phosphate-based solutions (sCaP) containing fluoride (F), with and without zinc (Zn) ions on reducing susceptibility to acid dissolution and Streptococcus mutans (S. mutans) colonization of dentin surfaces.

Methods: Dentin sections were treated with double distilled water (control) and with sCaP solutions differing in pH and in F− and/or Zn2+ ion concentrations. Solutions A (pH 7); B, C, and D (pH 5.5); solution C, twice Zn2+ and F− ion concentration compared to B; solution D is similar to C but without Zn2+. The dentin surfaces were characterized using scanning electron microscopy (SEM), x-ray diffraction, and Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy. Dissolution was determined in acidic buffer. Bacterial (S. mutans) attachment and growth were evaluated using SEM and Bioquant. Statistical analyses applied analysis of variance (ANOVA) and Duncan’s multiple Range test.

Results: Compared to control, dentin surfaces treated with sCaP solutions showed: (a) occluded dentin tubules; (b)reduced susceptibility to acid dissolution; and (c) Zn2+ ions were more effective than F− ions in inhibiting bacterial colonization.

Significance: Acidic sCaP containing both F and Zn ions have mineralizing, acid resistance, and antibacterial effects and may be potentially useful as a strategy against dentin caries formation and progression.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Acid produced by the fermentation of food carbohydrates by oral bacteria initiates the dentin caries process, that is, dissolution of the dentin mineral (apatite) followed by the breaking down of the organic matrix.1 Culture-based2 and culture-independent studies3 demonstrated that Streptococcus mutans (S. mutans) and lactobacilli are the principal microorganisms associated with root caries.

Root caries has become a significant oral health issue especially among the middle aged and the elderly with treated and untreated periodontal disease. Periodontal disease or its treatment leads to gingival recession resulting in the exposure of the root surfaces that become susceptible to caries development.4 Current remineralization-based therapies to prevent or arrest dentin orroot caries include mouth rinses,5 fluoridated dentifrices,6 varnishes,7 gels,8 and calcium phosphate solutions (sCap).9 The presence of fluoride (F−) ions increases the mineralizing efficiency of the sCaP and inhibits enamel dissolution by the formation of less soluble fluoridated hydroxyapatite.10,11 In addition, F− ions reduce the metabolism of oral bacteria.12

Prevention of bacterial adherence to tooth surfaces is considered an important strategy for dental caries control.13 Combining mineralizing agents with mechanical and/or chemical treatments to control bacterial plaque are deemed necessary for preventing and arresting root caries.14 An all-in-one F-releasing adhesives coated on the root dentin was shown to inhibit S.mutans biofilm formation through a protective layer covering exposed root dentinal surfaces.15

Zinc (Zn2+) ions released from Zn salts was shown to inhibit plaque formation and gingival inflammation.16 Polymer membranes mineralized with Zn-containing calcium phosphate (CaP) compound, inhibited bacterial growth.17 Zn-releasing CaP (Zn-ACP) coatings on orthodontic brackets inhibited in vitro bacterial growth.18

The present study aimed to determine the efficacy sCaP in increasing resistance to acid dissolution and inhibiting adherence and colonization of S. mutans on dentin surfaces. Similar solutions were shown to occlude dentin tubules in a recent study.19

sec.title: Solution preparations
sec.p:
Double distilled water (DDW) was the control solution. The experimental sCaP solutions (A, B, C, and D) were prepared from mixtures of Ca-deficient apatite (prepared by precipitation) and sodium F with (A, B, and C) or without (D) added zinc chloride (Fisher Scientific, New Jersey) and dilute phosphoric acid. The saturated solutions were filtered off from the undissolved mixture. The release of ions from the mixtures solution A had pH of 7, of solutions B, C, and D, pH 5.5. Solutions A and B had similar F− and Zn2+ ions concentration; solution C had twice Zn2+ and F− ion concentration compared to B; and solution D is similar to C but without Zn2+. The solution concentrations of Ca, P, and Zn ions were determined using inductive coupled plasma, ICP (Thermo Jarrell Ash Model, Waltham, MA, USA) and the solution F concentration by F-ion selective electrode (Metrohm 867 pH module) using appropriate standards. Solution composition and pH of the sCaP are listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Compositions (in ppm) and pHs of the sCaP solutions.
Solutions pH Ca (ppm) P (ppm) Zn (ppm) F (ppm)
Solution A 7.0 48.59 103.2 12.04 117.3
Solution B 5.5 50.54 101.9 15.02 152.2
Solution C 5.5 48.84 102.5 30.08 270.2
Solution D 5.5 55.62 100.0 0.03 258.1
Ca: calcium, F: fluoride, P = phosphate, Zn: zinc, sCaP: calcium phosphate-based solutions.

sec.title: Dentin section preparations
sec.p: Caries-free extracted human permanent molars obtained from the Department of Maxillofacial Surgery were stored in saline and sterilized by gamma radiation. The crowns were removed using a water-cooled diamond-bladed saw (Series 15 HC Diamond, N 11-4244, Buehler, USA) and the roots were attached to mounting stubs with epoxy resin. Buccal 1/2 or lingual 1/2 dentin sections were obtained by dividing the roots along the mesio-distal direction.19 The dentin sections were polished on one side sequentially using 320 grit, 600 grit, and then 1000 grit wet paper and a polishing wheel, ultrasonically cleaned, rinsed with DDW, and dried with compressed air.

The dentin sections (6 sections/group) were randomly distributed into the treated (Groups A, B, C, and D) and control groups reflecting the treatment solutions (Solutions A, B, C, and D) used. The sections were immersed in the solutions for 4 min rinsed with DDW and dried with compressed air.

sec.title: Characterization of dentin surfaces
sec.p: The dentin surfaces were characterized using x-ray diffraction(XRD; Philips X’ Pert X-ray diffractometer), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR; NicoletMagna IR 550 Spectrometer Series II, France), and scanning electron microscopy (SEM; Hitachi S-3500 N; Hitachi, Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). Crystallite sizes were determined from the broadening at half height width (β1/2) of the [002] diffraction peaks using the Debye-Scherrer formula.20

For the FT-IR analysis, 1 mg of the powdered material scraped from the treated dentin surfaces was mixed with 250 mg KBr and pressed at 10,000 psi (Carver laboratory press, mode C, Fred S. Carver Inc.). Absorption band assignments were based on those of carbonate apatites and other CaPs.21,22

For SEM analyses, the dentin sections were mounted on aluminum stubs and sputter coated with gold. SEM images were taken under the same magnification andworking distance, taking random 10 images per sample from selected fields in the cervical portion of each section.
For the XRD, FT-IR, and SEM analyses, 6 dentin sections per group per analyses were used.

sec.title: Dissolution experiments
sec.p: Nail varnish was applied on all parts of the dentin surfaces (three dentin sections per group) except for a circular area (diameter, 5 mm). Each dentin section was immersed in an acidic buffer (0.1 M KAc, pH 6, 37°C) for 90 min and the release of Ca2+ ions into the buffer with time was monitored using inductive coupled plasma (Thermo Jarrell Ash Model, Waltham, MA, USA). We speculated that 90-min immersion of the dentin sections in acidic buffer will be sufficient time to discriminate differences in the dissolution properties of the control and treated dentin surfaces and that longer time might involve the dissolution of the dentin below the coated surface and thus confound the results obtained.

sec.title: Bacterial adhesion and colonization experiments
sec.p: A reference strain of S. mutans ATCC 25175 (provided by Dr. Robert Boylan, New York University College of Dentistry) was suspended in 200 mL brain heart infusion broth and inoculated into brain heart infusion agar. After incubation in 5% CO2 in an anaerobic atmosphere at 37°C for 48 h, S. mutans was cultured in brain heart infusion broth overnight under the same anaerobic condition. The concentration of the bacterial culture was adjusted to 0.30 at OD600 using SynergyTM Multi-Detection Microplate Reader (BioTek Instruments Inc., USA).

sec.title: Bacterial adhesion experiment
sec.p: Each dentin sections (6 sections per group) were placed in 24-well plates (Corning). Two milliliter aliquots of the bacterial suspension were added to each well. The specimens were then incubated for 4 h at 37°C in an anaerobic atmosphere. The incubation time of 4 h was chosen based on reports that complete biofilm formation in the oral environment occurs in 2 to 4 h.23,24 After incubation, each section was washed three times with 5 mL of phosphate buffered saline (PBS). The samples were fixed for 1 h using Trumps fixative (glutaraldehyde in a mixture of sodium cacodylate buffer), washed in PBS, dehydrated using increasing concentrations of ethanol (50–100%), and dried using DCP-1 critical point drying apparatus (Enton Scuum Inc., USA).

sec.title: Bacterial colonization experiment
sec.p: The concentration of S. mutans ATCC 25173 cultures were adjusted to a turbidity of 0.30 at OD600, then 10-fold serial dilutions were prepared. The treated dentin sections (6 per group per time point of 8, 16, and 24 h) were placed in 24-well cell culture plates. Two mL aliquots of the 10-fold serial diluted bacterial culture were added to each well. The specimens were then incubated at 37°C in an anaerobic atmosphere. The samples were taken out after each time period, fixed, and dried as described above.

We compared two methods (i.e., turbidity measurement method and the SEM/Bioquant method) of assessing the number of viable bacteria. We found that the SEM/Bioquant method gave a better estimation of bacterial population. The SEM images were loaded in Bioquant program (Bioquant Nova Advanced Image Analysis apparatus, 200 R&M Biometrics, Inc.), using the manual measurement function to count the number of bacteria (10 random areas per specimen) on each image. This direct counting method may minimize the underestimation of bacteria population that are encountered using the usual turbidity measurement after sonicating bacteria from the samples and culturing for a period of time because even low frequency ultrasound could kill bacteria25 thereby causing loss of original data.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Data from XRD, SEM, FT-IR, and bacteria population were assessed by SPSS15.0 using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Student-Newman-Keuls or Dunnett's T3 post hoc. Dissolution experiment statistical analysis was conducted using multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) test within SAS 9.2 software. α = 0.05.

sec.title: Composition of dentin surfaces
sec.p:
Differences in the SEM images of dentin surfaces treated with sCaP solutions (A, B, C, and D) compared to control indicated that sCaP treatment formed coatings on the dentin surfaces (Figure 1(b) compared with Figure 1(d), (f), (h), and (j)). The amount of surface coating appeared to depend on the composition and pH of the solution. Groups B surfaces (solution pH 5.5) compared to Group A surfaces (solution pH 7; (Figure 1(f) compared to Figure 1(d)), and Groups C (higher F− and Zn2+ ion concentrations) and D (higher F− ion concentration but without Zn2+ ions) compared to Group B appeared to have higher amount of deposits (Figure 1(h) and (j) compared to Figure 1(f )). Figure 1.
SEM images of dentin surfaces after immersion in distilled water (control) (1a, 1b), in solution B (1c, 1d), in solution C (1e,1f), and in solution D (1g and 1h). After immersion, deposited crystals were seen on the dentin surfaces and inside dentin tubules. The diameters of the dentin tubules decreased (1a, 1c, 1e, and 1g: magnification, ×2K; 1b, 1d, 1f, and 1 h: magnification, ×20 K). SEM:scanning electron microscope.

The mean (±SD) crystallite size (in Angstroms) were: 187 ± 7 for control surfaces, 232 ± 31, 246 ± 31, and 295 ± 43, 305 ± 49 for apatite crystals from surfaces treated with solutions A, B, C, and D, respectively. Asignificant difference between control and Groups A, B, C, or D were observed. The crystallite size were bigger for Groups C and D than Groups B and A.

FT-IR spectra of the materials scraped from the dentin surfaces from all groups showed typical spectra of carbonate apatite characterized by absorption bandsattributed to the CO3 groups at about 1510 cm−1,1450 cm−1, and 873 cm−1 and to the PO4 group at about 1100 cm−1 to 1027 cm−1, 603 cm−1, and 562 cm−1.21 Absorption band at 1653 cm−1 is attributed to the amide (NH2) groups in the organic phase (collagen). The PO4 absorption bands (1102, 1065, and 1027 cm−1) in the spectra of apatite from the dentin surfaces of groups C or D compared to those from Groups A or B had higher resolution. The organic/inorganic ratio represented by the NH2/CO3 absorption band intensity ratios were 1.66 ± 0.14 for the control surface; 1.36 ± 0.09, 1.38 ± 0.12, 1.07 ± 0.09, and 1.03 ± 0.13 for surfaces treated with solutions A, B, C, and D, respectively. The ratio was lower for groups C and D compared to groups A and B.

sec.title: Dissolution properties
sec.p:
The amount of Ca2+ ions released in the acidic buffer in 90 min was higher for control group and group A compared to that for groups B, C, or group D surfaces. Groups C or D surfaces exhibited the lowest value. *P < 0.01, n = 3 for each group (Figure 2). Figure 2.
Dissolution curves showing comparative Ca2+ ion concentration released in the acidic buffer from the control and treated dentin surfaces. The amount of Ca2+ ions released in 90 min in acidic buffer was higher for the dentin surfaces treated with DDW (control) or that treated with solution B compared with surfaces treated with solution C or solution D. The surfaces treated with solution C exhibited the lowest value (*p < 0.01). DDW: double distilled water.

sec.title: Inhibition of bacterial attachment and growth
sec.p:
After 4 h in culture, the population of S. mutans ATCC 25175 attached on control (Figure 3(a), (c), (e)) or group D (Figure 3(f)) were greater than that on groups A, B (Figure 3(g) and (h)) and group C (Figure 3(b) and (d)) dentin surfaces. Dentin sections treated with solutions A, B, or C inhibited S. mutans ATCC 25175 attachment. However, there was no visual difference between the bacterial population adhering on the control (Figure 3(e)) and group D (Figure 3(f )) surfaces. Figure 3.
SEM images showing greater population of S. mutans ATCC 25175 attached on control dentin surfaces (a and c) compared to those on surfaces treated with solution C (b and d). A greater number of bacteria attached into the open dentin tubules on control dentin surfaces (c) compared with those observed on the occluded dentin tubules of dentin treated with solution C (d). Dentin surfaces treated with solution D (f) compared to control (e) showed higher number of occluded dentin tubules but the attached bacterial population was not significantly less. Dentin surfaces treated with solution A (g) and B (h) showed inhibition of bacterial population attachment (a and b: magnification, ×1 K; c and d: magnification, ×10 K; e and f: magnification, ×2 K; g and h magnification ×2 K). SEM: scanning electron microscope.

The mean number for the bacteria colonized on groups A, B, or C surfaces was significantly less than that on the control or group D at the three time points. There was no significant difference in the bacterial colonization inhibition among dentin surfaces treated with solutions A, B, or C (Figure 4). Figure 4.
Graphs showing the mean number for S. mutans ATCC 25175 colonization on control dentin surfaces and surfaces treated with solutions B, C, or D after 8, 16, and 24 h in culture. Dilution of the bacterial concentration of 0.3 at OD600 used for the 8, 16, and 24 h time period was 10 times, 100 times, and 1000 times, respectively. There was a significant difference between colonization on control and surfaces with solutions A, B, and C, but not with those treated with solution D (**p < 0.01,#p < 0.05).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Dentin surfaces treated with saturated sCaP used in this study provided coatings that were less susceptible to acid dissolution and that were less susceptible to S.mutans colonization compared to those treated with distilled water (control). Solution C with lower pH (5.5) and containing both F− and Zn2+ ions were more effective than solutions with neutral pH (pH 7, solution A), or solution B containing half F− and Zn2+ ion concentrations of solution C, or solution containing only F− ions (solution D). In addition, the solution C-treated surfaces showed significant number of occluded dentin tubules and tubules with smaller diameters.

Deposition of a coatings on the dentin surfaces treated with sCaPs were indicated by differences in: (a) surface morphology (from SEM images); (b) crystallite size (X-ray diffraction and FT-IR analyses); (c) organic/inorganic ratio of materials scraped from dentin surfaces (FTIR analyses); and (d) dissolution properties. The amount deposited is greater from solutions with lower pH and/or higher concentrations of F− and Zn2+ ions. Solutions with lower pH (solutions B, C, and D) are expected to cause partial dissolution of the dentin mineral, which would cause greater amounts of Ca and P ions to be released compared with the solution with neutral pH (solution A).

The larger crystal size of apatite deposited on dentin surfaces treated with solutions C and D and the less susceptibility to acid dissolution of these treated surfaces are due to the incorporation of F− ions in the apatite.22,26 Our recent study showed that occlusions in the dentin tubule (from treatment with either solutions B or C) still remained even after 1-h exposure to acidic buffer.19 Although it has been shown that the incorporation of Zn2+ ions increase the solubility of apatite22 or tricalcium phosphate27 in cases where Zn2+ and F− ions were simultaneously incorporated, the F− effect was more dominant.28 In addition, acid exposure of the dentin surfaces treated with sCaP solutions could lead to partial dissolution of the coating releasing Ca, P, and F ions to the micro-environment that will inhibit further dissolution of the dentin surface. It has been shown that solution containing Ca, P, and F ions simultaneously was most effective in inhibiting the dissolution of synthetic or enamel apatite compared to solutions containing (Ca + P), (Ca + F), or (P + F) or F ions alone.22

The mechanism for the observed cariostatic effect of F is a combination of the following effects: (a)forming (F, OH)-apatite crystals that are more acid-resistant;11,22,29 (b) enhancing mineralization; (c)reducing the metabolism of oral bacteria,12 and (e) formation of “CaF2.” The contribution of the antibacterial effect of F to its cariostatic property is still debated.30

A study using a biofilm model showed no difference in the initial growth (initial 20 h) of S. mutants between F-free and F-substituted apatite and that only at low environmental pH (pH 5.5) or under glucose excess, was the S. mutans cells accumulation on the F- apatite surfaces significantly reduced.31

Our results showed that dentin surfaces treated with solutions containing Zn2+ ions in addition to the Ca2+, HPO4− and F− ions (solutions B or C) inhibited bacterial attachment and colonization. Although solution C had double the Zn2+ ion concentration of solutions A or B, dentin sections treated with solution C showed no higher antibacterial effect compared to solutions A or B. The dentin surfaces treated with solution D, which had the similar F− ion concentration as solution C but did not contain Zn2+ ions, had no significant antibacterial property. However, surfaces treated with either solution A, B, or C (containing both F− and Zn2+ ions) inhibited bacterial attachment and colonization compared to those treated with DDW (control) or solution D. These results suggest that the Zn2+ ions were more effective than the F− ions (at least at the F− ion concentrations used in this study) in inhibiting bacterial adherence and colonization. It is also possible that Zn2+ and F− ions act synergistically in inhibiting bacterial colonization. Further studies are needed to clarify this issue.

In conclusion, results of our study suggest that acidic sCaP containing both F and Zn ions have mineralizing, acid resistance, and antibacterial effects and may be potentially useful as a treatment strategy against dentin caries formation and progression.
